ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: The Mark and Brad Show was a great way to end my academic studies at Yale. This course is definitely anideal 'capstone' course for students that are interested in environmental management / working with a client / design. I think it was also really valuable to produce something for Yale. However, I do almost wish the course had been split into two semesters-- one semester developing the ecosystem services framework (and defining each service) and the second semester applying it to different parts of campus. I felt like towards the end of the semester everyone got burnt out and we could have produced a lot more work with more time and thought. Overall, however, I think this is the best course I've taken at FES.

How clearly did the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?Out of class assignments for this course were _______________ to my learning.How responsive to student comments was the instructor?I learned a lot from field trips/lab work:The class was divided into two sections- one focusing on exploring an ecosystem service and one on drafting a plan for a part of campus. The exploration of each ecosystem service suffered from the artificial separation of one ecosystem service from another. None really functions without the others, so the decision to separate had enormous impact on the usefulness of the work. To make a case why Yale should pursue one ecosystem service over another (be it biodiversity, aesthetics, climate, or water) weakens the very thing- interconnectedness- that makes such an approach compelling.So the explanation of conceptual material was constantly compromised by the attempt to keep ecosystem services separate. This was simple but huge and it kept us turning around in circles instead of moving forward in our understanding of ecosystem services in the built environment.Both assignments were done in groups. The paper on an ecosystem service was somewhat helpful to my understanding of ecosystem services. More helpful was the development of a plan for a part of campus. I wish we had devoted much more time to this part of the class.The professors were both fantastic. This was a learning experience for them as well and they never suggested that they already knew the answers. It definitely felt like a partnership with consistent conversation.The field trip wasn't so helpful for me. Everything I saw there, I already knew about and understood. Many of the meetings were with people who are working with the market but since this class wasn't engaged with the market, this wasn't useful at all. Sure, it was interesting, but I can only absorb so much information at once! The trip was really over-scheduled. Free time to explorethe city would have been useful for getting first hand knowledge on how things work.

I think trying to do both the baseline for what ecosystem services are, and making recommendations for specific parts of campus, was too much for one semester. I understand the reason for both, but we were limited at a conceptual level for both because of the time available... Not necessarily a bad thing, but it does make providing a solid analysis much harder. If we had only done one, I actually preferred the second part, because it gave us the ability to get creative with a specific area of campus. That wouldn't work as well if people didn't already have background, but in this case I think it would have because almost everyone in the class already had experience with green infrastructure to some degree.

I really enjoyed this course. I experienced some difficulty in my group. I would suggest closer monitoring of the groups. I would not advocate specifying roles for each group member. I would let the groups form on their own. However, closer monitoring may alleviate some of the difficulty the groups found.
The course was a great learning experience. It was different than what I initially expected it to be but turned out well.
Good class because it allows brings together theory and practice.
The experimental nature of the class. We were researching something on which no one group or person is an expert. It was challenging but very educational to research ecosystem services.

The best thing about this class was the environment of collaboration and respect. The next best thing was that the Yale Office of Sustainability was directly involved, so our work will have real impact.
The cameraderie of the class and the flexibility of the instructors.
The give and take between the theoretical and the applied.
Field trip to Portland, great involvement of office of sustainability staff
field trip.
This class was challenging, but the attention Mark and Brad gave to us as we all struggled with the coming up with our conceptual frameworks was amazing.
The instructors--they were the best and most dedicated instructors I've had at FES.
One of the best classes I took at Yale FES.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: I think the class went smoothly - if anything I would say there needs to be better consensus from the client side on what they want as an outcome as there were a lot of conflicting expectations.
The field trip to Portland was great-- but a little tiring.. Next time the class should have more "free time"...
Trip organization needs to improve. A balance of meetings that correspond to the class and free time.The separation of ecosystem services needs to be revisited.
Clearer identification of course objectives at the beginning
I think we should have spent time on figuring out costs and tradeoffs. I also wish Brad and Mark would have shared more of their knowledge on these issues.

The field trip was great--lots of activities and interesting people to meet, however, I felt like it was too jam-packed. I think we could have gotten more out of it if we focused in on a fewer people and organizations. A day to explore on our own would have also been a great way to explore things each of us are interested in on an individual level.This course changes subject matter each year, but I think in terms of organization, starting off with the delineated campus zones would have been a great way to frame the class. It's hard to parse out ecosystem services as separate entities, and I think both Yale and the students would have made better use of time and energy if it was devoted to campus specific areas from the get-go.
Consider doing the mid-term student teamwork evaluations after all the midterm work is complete.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: The professors and TAs were always available.
Max and Randy were great TAs.

Instructors were fantastic, fantastic, fantastic. They were always available and they went above and beyond in every way.Brad is always thinking, always has great questions that help everyone deepen their own thinking, and is a consistently constructive critic.Mark is inspiring, challenging us incorporate science into our proposals, and is committed to empowering students.
The professors were eager to meet with any teams who needed it. We did this in some cases, and received good feedback - as well as on our written reports.
Very helpful and very responsive.
Instructors were very involved and a available, offered exceptional guidance. I appreciate the great effort the ta put into the course. Great job!
Great
The instructors were great--always available and willing to meet and talk things over.

The instructors were unbelievably helpful. I really appreciated their attempts to set all students at ease, create a jocular atmosphere, and so much of their time and effort responding to iterations of our papers and presentations. The instructors set an amazing example.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This course fit very well into my overall program.
This course fit perfectly into my program because it lies at the intersection of theory and practice. Implementation is my priority and the priority of this class was implementation.
its a good course that allowed us to understand how implementing innovative strategies involve understanding and being aware of institutional constraints.

I'm interested in sustainable land management and urban ecology--this class provided a great way to get to know the ins and outs of conceptualizing these fields for Yale. I also learned a whole lot about administrative and corporate structure at Yale. Whoa. What a beast!

This class gave me the ability to reflect on professional skills at a very high level by encouraging learning-by-doing, by exposing me to top-level professionals whose colleague I was for the duration of the project, and via the field-trip.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I knew very little (or rather, I thought I knew very little) about ecosystem services.
I took this class because it focused on implementation. My interests lie at the intersection of theory and practice, so this was a perfect fit.

I took this course because I was asked by Max and Randy to contribute on Biodiversity. My knowledge of the topic is respected. I have trained in it for years. My expectations of the course were met when I worked with them in th last half of the course. It was rigorously difficult prior to that.
Capstone, project-based course working with a client
Interest in ecosystem services.
I took this class because I'm interested in the topic but also because of the reputations Mark and Brad have as being among the best professors at FES.
I thought it would help me get a job. And I wanted to study with Brad and Mark.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes but I would have liked to have gotten into the cost/savings more.
It did. We had some highs and some lows but we worked through them together and I am really happy with the outcome.
It did in the last half of the semester. I did not gain much from the first half of the semester.
Yes and No. I feel like doing something on the cost part would have been important.

I think there were a number of times when everyone in this class felt frustrated, burnt out, and overwhelmed for one reason or another. That said, I learned an incredible amount, appreciated the degree to which we were able to interface with Office of Sustainability, and the amount of time dedicated to presenting our thoughts and ideas in an open format.
I have a job--but it doesn't have much to do with the class. Having the opportunity to study with Brad and Mark will leave its mark on me for the rest of my professional career.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
I did.
yes and no. I got the concepts.
Yes, see above.

I didn't expect this class to have such an enormous impact on me, but it did! I didn't expect our clients to respond favorably to our proposal, but they did. I didn't expect to learn so much about professional skills and different styles, or to feel like I learned so much from each and every student in the class. Thanks to the professors' teaching style, all this and more was possible.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: There was A LOT of group work. I think the feedback on the group work is probably covered in the evaluations we filled out. There was far more work outside of the classroom than I envisioned there would be.

Advantages were that a good group is more than the sum of its parts. Disadvantages were that a bad group is also more than the sum of its parts. I think that designating a project manager for each group, as is done in the office environment, would improve the group work process.

I was lucky enough to have two teams who worked well together. This allowed us to divide up the work, reducing the load on each of us, and also made the work stronger because we all had complementary expertise.The disadvantage is that we had a large amount of work to do in a short amount of time, and I know that a lot of groups had conflict through differences of opinion and/or work styles.

The advantages of working in the group were a wealth of information coming from the first half of the semester to the second. The second half of the semester the advantages were goal attainment from conceptual framework to applied examples. A detail in the work and a successful effort in creating a central campus ecosystems services plan.
The first group there was a lot of tension. Thesecond group was great. Not sure what the difference was.

This was the hardest group work I've ever participated in at FES (and almost every class I've taken has involved a group project). I was part of a group that had issues from the beginning. When I look back, I think there is more I could have done to smooth these issues over. I learned a lot of from this experience, and think I'll be better able to handle tricky dynamics in the future.
Advantages--I learned a lot about time management and deepened my ability to act as a professional.Disadvatanges--I ended up doing much more than my share of the work in both work groups.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take the class!

As long as the topic of the course, which changes each year, interests you, this class is a fantastic way of applying everything you've been learning to the real world. And you get to do it without as much risk as in the real world because, in the end, it is still a class.Brad and Mark are a great duo, really complement each other, I would highly recommend the class.If you don't like group work, this isn't for you.
The course evolvesas the semester progresses, keep an open mind to changing initial expectations
Its a good class. But be aware that it is mostly about what the students make out of. The professors rarely lecture.
Mark and Brad are terrific teachers and great resources--use them often!
Take it!!!
